Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 53354-001  
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance Cluster (C-KSTA) 
August 2020 
 
 
 
Supporting Evaluations for Development 
Effectiveness in Asia and the Pacific, 2020–2024  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Distribution of this document is restricted until it has been approved by the Board of Directors. 
Following such approval, ADB will disclose the document to the public in accordance with ADB’s 
Access to Information Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADF  –  Asian Development Fund 
  CAPE  –  country assistance program evaluation 
  CE  –  corporate evaluation 
  C-KSTA  –  knowledge and support technical assistance cluster 
  COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 
  CPS  –  country partnership strategy 
  DEC  –  Development Effectiveness Committee 
  EAP  –  evaluation approach paper 
  IED  −  Independent Evaluation Department 
  MARS  −  Management Action Record System 
  NSO  −  nonsovereign operations 
  PCR  −  project or program completion report 
  PPER  –  project or program performance evaluation report 
  PPP  –  public–private partnerships 
  SAPE  −  sector assistance program evaluation 
  SDG  −  Sustainable Development Goal 
SE  –  sector-wide evaluation 
  SPS  –  safeguard policy statement 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TCR  −  Technical assistance completion report 
  TASF  −  Technical Assistance Special Fund 
TE  –  thematic evaluation 
  TOR  –  terms of reference 
  XARR  –  extended annual review report 
 
 
 
NOTE{S} 
 
In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
   
Director General  Marvin Taylor-Dormond, Independent Evaluation Department (IED) 
Deputy Director General  Veronique N. Salze-Lozac'h, IED 
   
Team leader  Benjamin Graham, Principal Evaluation Specialist, IED  
Team members  Renato Lumain, Senior Evaluation Officer, IED 
  Karina Paula Marquez, Evaluation Assistant, IED 
   
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance will support evaluations of ADB and its operations in the 
Asia and Pacific region. Independent evaluation is essential for good corporate governance and 
the results focus of multilateral development banks. This technical assistance (TA) for the 
Independent  Evaluation  department  (IED)  will  support  evaluations  to  help  improve  the 
effectiveness of Asian Development Bank (ADB) policies, business processes, and operations in 
the Asia and Pacific region.1  
 
2.  The TA is anchored in the Board-approved evaluation work program. Evaluations 
supported by the cluster knowledge and support technical assistance (C-KSTA) will be conducted 
over the 2020−2024 period, in line with IED’s annual 3−year rolling work programs.2 The current 
work program covering the 2020–2022 period was endorsed by the Development Effectiveness 
Committee (DEC) and approved by the Board of Directors on 12 December 2019.3 In carrying out 
its function, IED follows internationally accepted principles and standards. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  With significant development progress have come complex challenges. The region 
has reduced poverty and advanced development across many dimensions. At the same time, 
income and non-income disparities, environmental degradation, climate change, health risks, and 
fragility persist or have worsened. The ongoing coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic is 
already affecting the region’s ability to achieve inclusive, resilient, and sustainable development.  
 
4.  These challenges demand a more ambitious global agenda. Intensifying and more 
complex challenges have brought about a more ambitious and aspirational global development 
agenda. The Sustainable Development Goals, the Paris Agreement, and other recently adopted 
global and regional agendas collectively embody a new deal for global development that aims to 
tackle the most pressing problems while seizing the most important opportunities. 
 
5.  Achieving this agenda will require stronger development effectiveness. Realizing 
inclusive, resilient, and sustainable development in the face of mounting challenges, in particular, 
the COVID-19 pandemic will require not only greater but also more effective use of development 
resources. This in turn requires that development assistance processes be strengthened. This 
carries important implications for development institutions like ADB. 
 
6.  A stronger, better, and faster ADB requires continual learning and improvement. 
ADB’s new Strategy 20304 and stronger financial base, owing to the combination of the Asian 
Development Fund (ADF) and ordinary capital resources, will support its higher qualitative and 
quantitative ambitions, but becoming a stronger, better, and faster institution will also require 
continual reflection and improvement. In addition to its core business of financing projects, ADB 
will need to strengthen its ability to derive and deploy knowledge and leverage partnerships. 
Independent evaluation makes an important contribution to this ongoing process. 
 
1 The concept paper for this C-KSTA was approved by director general, IED on 13 May 2020.   
2  The C-KSTA cluster first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 20 May 2020. The C-
KSTA is divided into three subprojects. Subproject 1 will support the delivery of evaluations to be mobilized in 2020 
and completed through 2022, as set out in the current IED work program. Subproject 2 is structured along the same 
lines and will support the delivery of evaluations in 2022−2023, based on the next 3-year work program.  Subproject 
3 will support the delivery of evaluations in 2023−2024, based on the work program cycle for that period. 
3  https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/page/110939/WP-2020-2022.pdf 
4  https://www.adb.org/documents/strategy-2030-prosperous-inclusive-resilient-sustainable-asia-pacific

2 
 
7.  Independent evaluation supports development effectiveness in the region. Through 
evaluation, IED aims to help ADB and member countries achieve better development results. In 
line with Strategy 2030, evaluation intends to shed light on the critical challenges facing the region 
(Supplementary Appendix 1). As ADB operations expand under Strategy 2030, the role of its 
independent evaluation function must also expand, in the interest of accountability and learning. 
 
8.  IED plans a real-time evaluation of ADB’s response to COVID-19. The evaluation will 
start in 2020 and be completed in mid-2021 and will examine ADB’s response to the pandemic 
and its support for member countries. As the crisis evolves and significant resources are mobilized 
in response, it is critical that early lessons are documented. In addition, IED will: develop new 
desk and online-based approaches, processes, and products; issue short evaluation knowledge 
notes on issues directly relevant to the COVID-19 crisis; and provide real-time comments and 
input to ADB as it prepares programs to help countries respond to the crisis.  
 
III.  JUSTIFICATION FOR CLUSTER MODALITY 
9.  A cluster TA modality is the most appropriate way of funding IED’s 3-year rolling 
work programs. These are strategically linked with a common overall objective. For example, 
the 2020−2022 work program aligns with ADB’s corporate strategies and the operational priorities 
of Strategy 2030. The cluster modality enables funding to be flexibly designed and implemented. 
It allows better sequencing of TA activities compared with stand-alone TA projects that are 
processed annually and that do not fit well with the rolling work program. 
 
10.  The TA builds on earlier lessons and experience to improve efficiency. Until 2016, 
IED processed TA projects on a yearly basis, which complicated planning and delivery processes. 
Yearly TA preparation and approvals required an inordinate amount of administrative work, with 
approvals required from both Management and the Board and frequent scope changes to keep 
the TA updated. The shift to a cluster modality streamlined the process for IED, Management, 
and the Board, while adding flexibility. Another lesson is the importance of knowledge sharing, 
capacity development, and outreach to increase the learning from and use of evaluations.  
 
11.  The TA will support a strategic mix of evaluations over the medium term. IED draws 
on both its annual administrative budget and TA resources to deliver its work programs. By 
combining these resources, IED can plan and deliver timely, relevant, and high-quality evaluations 
and knowledge activities. This proposed C-KSTA for 2020–2024 follows an earlier cluster TA 
approved in 2016.5 Like the first cluster TA, the proposed C-KSTA will support the delivery of a 
 
5 ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance Report: Selected Evaluation Studies and Outreach for 2017-2019. Manila. The third 
and final subproject was approved in December 2018 and will be completed in 2021. To date, the committed amount 
for the 2016 Cluster TA is 85%, with 81% of contracts disbursed, and overall 68% of total TA resources disbursed. 
Two earlier stand-alone TA projects were approved in 2014 (TA 8653) and 2015 (TA 8928) to support mid- and high-
level evaluation studies and outreach activities, of which IED has disbursed 78% and 90% of TA funds, respectively. 
IED will spend down the remaining TA resources in 2020, with the intention of closing the two TA projects in early 
2021. The two stand-alone TAs are: ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance Report: Selected Evaluation Studies for 2014. 
Manila; ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance Report: Selected Evaluation Studies for 2015. Manila. Evaluations in 2020 
and 2021, the transition period between the two cluster TAs, may draw on both the earlier C-KSTA or stand-alone 
TAs as well as the new C-KSTA. Evaluations that draw on more than one TA will be clearly identified in each TA 
completion report as having been partially funded by that TA.

3 
mix of evaluations and validations, including some complementary knowledge and outreach 
activities.6 
 
12.  Prior evaluations have made important contributions to ADB policies, strategies, 
and operations. Examples of the wide range of evaluations that have been supported by earlier 
TA resources are listed in Table 1. These evaluations have helped to strengthen ADB’s policies, 
strategies, and programs across a range of sectors and thematic areas, modalities and facilities, 
and country programs. As reported in IED’s 2020 Annual Evaluation Review, about 77% of IED 
evaluation  recommendations  are  accepted  by  ADB  Management,  and  of  these  70%  are 
implemented.7 IED will try to incrementally raise these levels in the forthcoming C-KSTA period.

IV.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
A.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
13.  The TA is aligned with the impact of improved development effectiveness of ADB 
operations, policies, and business processes.8 The TA will have the outcome of increased 
use of and learning from evaluations and their recommendations by the DEC, ADB Management 
and staff, and broader stakeholders (Appendix 1). The implicit theory of change holds that under 
the 2020–2022 work program, IED will deliver a combination of evaluations that are strategically 
and operationally relevant to Strategy 2030. These evaluations, combined with knowledge and 
learning support, will in turn support more effective ADB policies, processes, and operations. 
 
14.  The delivery of timely and high-quality evaluation outputs will support the outcome. 
IED plans to deliver a strategic mix of relevant, timely, and evidence-based evaluations using 
appropriate methods and technologies (outputs 1–4).9 These outputs are described below. 
Descriptions of the major evaluations for 2020–2022 are in Supplementary Appendix 2. 
 
 
6 IED uses TA resources primarily to support higher-level evaluations, while its administrative budget primarily supports 
lower-level evaluations and validations and other evaluation related operations. The staff consultant budget was $2.3 
million in both 2018 and 2019 and $2.4 million in 2020.   
7 IED. 2020. Annual Evaluation Review 2020. Manila: ADB.  
8 The TA aligns to IED’s role and function as set out in the ADB evaluation policy: ADB. 2008. Policy Paper: Review of 
the Independence and Effectiveness of the Operations Evaluation Department. Manila. 
9 Subprojects 1, 2 and 3 of the C-KSTA will have the same outputs.

4 
15.  Output 1: corporate and thematic evaluations delivered. IED will deliver a strategic 
mix of high-quality corporate and thematic evaluations with direct relevance to Strategy 2030. 
Recent evaluations have covered topics including small and medium-sized enterprises, gender 
and development, safeguards, and the ADF (Table 1). Planned evaluations include climate 
change,  COVID-19,  finance  and  public  financial  management  sectors,  ADB’s  procurement 
system, and credit and risk management (refer to Supplementary Appendix 3). 
 
16.  Output 2: country and subregional evaluations and validations delivered. IED has 
completed  many  country-level  evaluations  and  validations  in  recent  years  and  a  country 
evaluation on Bangladesh and validations of several country partnership strategy (CPS) final 
reviews are ongoing. IED plans to undertake subregional evaluations of the Greater Mekong 
Subregion and the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation programs. It also plans to 
conduct validations of CPS final reviews for a wide range of countries (the number depends on 
ADB’s CPS cycle). At least one country assistance program evaluation (CAPE) is planned for 
each year. These outputs will feed into ADB’s CPS planning and Board approval cycles.  
 
17.  Output 3: sector evaluations delivered. The re-introduction of evaluations covering 
ADB’s assistance in specific sectors across countries has been appreciated by the Board and 
ADB  Management.  IED  plans  to  undertake  sector-level  evaluations,  in  the  form  of  sector 
assistance program evaluations (SAPEs), sector-wide evaluations, and sector synthesis notes, in 
line with the thematic perspective of Strategy 2030. SAPE and sector-wide evaluations have 
recently covered agriculture, energy, transport, finance in Indonesia, and energy in Pakistan. 
Planned evaluations will cover finance and water and urban services. Sector synthesis notes will 
cover environment and social safeguards in both sovereign and nonsovereign operations. 
 
18.  Output 4: complementary and quick turn-around evaluation work delivered. IED 
plans to undertake a systematic review and a topical paper annually over the next 3 years. These 
complementary outputs will focus on policy-based lending by multilateral development banks, 
women’s economic empowerment, energy, and possibly climate change or finance. IED will 
remain ready to respond to requests for quick turn-around and other complementary evaluations, 
and to disseminate knowledge from its products at forums or publications.  
 
19.  IED will provide complementary EKM support and improve its information systems. 
IED will complement the delivery of evaluations with EKM activities, consisting of knowledge 
sharing, capacity development, outreach, and communication, targeting different internal and 
external audiences.10 This will raise the visibility and use of evaluation evidence among IED’s key 
stakeholders: the ADB Board and DEC, ADB Management and staff, and country agencies and 
stakeholders. IED will improve and modernize its information systems for its core evaluation work 
and manage and disseminate evaluation  knowledge.11 These include the IED subsite, the 
Management Action Record System (MARS), the Evaluation Information System (the lessons 
database and management dashboard), the Cognitive Search initiative for evaluation lessons 
(EVA) and other high-level analytical products. 
 
20.  Several risks have been identified in implementing the TA. These include unexpected 
shifts in strategic or policy directions by ADB and/or its member countries, lack of or poor quality 
 
10 Seminars,  workshops,  and  conferences  aim  to  gather  information  for  draft  report  and  support  high−level 
consultations. On a case-by case basis, the C-KSTA may also fund outreach activities, as specified in the Evaluation 
Knowledge Management team’s work plan and in dissemination plans at the inception stage of an evaluation. 
11 The C-KSTA will support consultant services for key system development and enhancements, where needed. This 
will complement the administrative budget support, continuing maintenance, and ad hoc technical support. C-KSTA 
support is estimated at around $30,000 annually

5 
of data, delays to or disruption of country missions, difficulty in recruiting consultants, and the 
need to adapt to unforeseen crises such as COVID-19. IED will monitor and manage these risks 
to ensure they do not jeopardize the efficient and effective delivery of its work program. 
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
21.  The TA is estimated to cost $6.5 million. This will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF−6)  and  TASF−other  sources. 12  Detailed  cost 
estimates  and  financing  arrangements  will  be  presented  for  each  TA  subproject  proposal 
submitted for approval. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  IED will modify its work plans in line with the evolving COVID-19 pandemic. Given 
that country missions have been curtailed during most or all of 2020, the work plan will be adapted 
to prioritize evaluations that are less dependent on travel. Some re-arrangement in the timing of 
evaluations will be unavoidable. IED is assessing the changes needed for evaluations due in 2020 
and early 2021 on a case-by-case basis. IED will continue to engage and consult with relevant 
ADB departments, including resident missions, in all evaluations. 
 
23.  ADB is the executing agency while IED will implement the TA. Each TA subproject 
proposal will be submitted for approval to director general, IED or his/her delegated authority, in 
accordance with the business process for knowledge and support TA cluster processing.13 IED 
divisions will implement the TA and supervise planned studies and/or knowledge and outreach 
activities. TA subproject activities will start only after approval. IED will coordinate with relevant 
regional departments, resident missions, and government agencies during implementation of 
evaluations and obtain no-objection approval from governments before fielding missions.14 
 
24.  Subprojects:  the  TA  will  be  implemented  through  three  subprojects.  Program 
implementation will be flexible to accommodate alterations in IED’s work plan.15 Each subproject 
will be designed to support the achievement of the cluster outputs 1-4 as and when needed during 
the implementation period.16 These are shown in Table 2 and described in Appendix 2. 
 
 
 
 
 
12 The C-KSTA projects will cover a mix of Group A, B and C countries. Both funding sources are available for all three 
subprojects. Evaluations covering a single Group C country will be funded from TASF−other sources. The breakdown 
for the $2.25 million for subproject is: TASF-6 $1.75 million, and TASF-other $ 0.50 million. TASF allocations for 
subprojects 2 and 3 will be financed by the TASF’s annual resource allocation to IED in the subsequent years, and 
the sources of financing (TASF-6 verses TASF-other) will be confirmed at that time. 
13 See the staff instruction on business processes for knowledge and support TA 
14 To ensure completeness and factual accuracy, key informant interviews will be held within and outside ADB.  The 
IED Quality Assurance Handbook requires consultations with relevant ADB departments and field offices at all 
phases of report preparation: inception; report preparation, and completion. IED receives ADB-wide feedback during 
the interdepartmental review of its draft approach paper and evaluation report. As appropriate, IED peer reviewers 
include subject experts from within ADB. Before finalizing a draft paper, IED discusses the post-interdepartmental 
review draft at a meeting of a heads of departments and offices and at a technical meeting on the evaluation 
recommendations.  
15 IED will consult with the DEC on changes in the approved work program, where appropriate. 
16 Detailed implementation arrangements, including consultants’ terms of reference, will be presented in each 
subproject report processed under the cluster.

6

25.  Consulting  services  will  be  procured  under  all  subprojects.17 Implementation 
arrangements for ADB procurement will be finalized prior to approval of the evaluation approach 
paper (Table 3).18

26.  International and/or national consultants and firms will be engaged. Lump-sum or 
output-based contracts will be used as appropriate. A firm may be recruited, guided by quality- 
and cost-based selection with a 90:10 quality-to-cost ratio as the default selection method. The 
C-KSTA will support the (i) engagement of sector and thematic specialists and researchers to 
help  conduct  in-depth  analysis  and/or  give  expert  inputs  on  the  development  context  and 
challenges during report preparation, i.e., data collection, surveys and processing, quantitative 
and  qualitative  analyses,  background  analytical  papers,  and  main  report  preparation;  
(ii) engagement of external experts for independent peer reviews; and (iii) engagement of 
resource persons and/or coordinators to help organize outreach and knowledge-sharing activities 
(refer to Supplementary Appendix 4). The consultants will be engaged in accordance with the 
ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions). 
 
 
17 Consultant−related costs are estimated to be 90%−95% of the total C-KSTA cost. 
18 Attachment 1 of the Staff Instruction on Business Processes for Knowledge and Support TA.

7 
27.  The purchase of evaluation tools, supplies and services will be for core evaluation 
and dissemination work such as conducting seminars, and/or workshops and surveys.19 
These will include programming and database tools, analytical instruments, and services as 
inputs during report preparation and supplies and services for seminars, workshops, and surveys. 
Procurement  will  be  on  a  case-by-case  basis  and  vetted  by  IED  management.20 IED  will 
coordinate with the Controller’s Department; Office of Administrative Services; Office of the 
General Counsel; Office of Information Systems and Technology; and the Procurement, Portfolio 
and Financial Management Department, where needed. 
 
28.  During  implementation,  evaluations  will  be  complemented  by  investments  in 
information services and knowledge sharing. As indicated (paragraph 19), IED will engage 
with targeted stakeholders through various avenues and learning events and will continually 
invest in its information systems. Dissemination of outputs will be in accordance with IED’s 
evaluation policy, particularly on public disclosure, dissemination, and lessons. In order to make 
evaluation knowledge more accessible, valued and used by various audiences, IED’s first EKM 
strategic plan conveys the learning side of evaluation and gives directions and a framework for 
EKM activities (outreach, communication, capacity development) in implementing approaches, 
developing new products, and organizing events to reach out to target audiences.  
 
29.  Areas for due diligence will be identified at the inception stage of an evaluation 
activity. Areas that may need to be confirmed, assessed, and discussed include knowledge 
partnerships (outreach events, networking); transfer of funds (outreach, information systems); 
procurement (outreach, events); printing publications (outreach); and social media and websites 
(outreach, information systems). Details will be decided prior to approval of the evaluation 
approach paper (EAP) and concept paper. Implementation will follow ADB’s process and due 
diligence procedures.21  
 
30.  On  a  case-by-case  basis,  funds  will  be  transferred.  Knowledge  partnership 
arrangements may be supported under the TA subprojects. IED will identify and process these in 
the context of the continuing needs of its core evaluation and knowledge work.  Processing of 
knowledge partnerships will follow ADB process and due diligence procedures.   
 
D.  Governance 
 
31.  The need for governance assessments, in any TA subproject, will be determined during 
the preparation of an evaluation or activity (before finalization of the EAP and concept paper).22 
IED will consult with the Office of Anticorruption and Integrity on disclosure, if needed.  
 
V.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
32.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $6,500,000 on a grant basis for the Knowledge and Support 
Technical Assistance Cluster on Supporting Evaluations for Development Effectiveness in Asia 
and the Pacific, 2020−2024. 
 
19 Evaluation teams carry out seminars, workshops, and data gathering through surveys, consultations, and knowledge 
sharing. The activities are typically finalized at the evaluation approach paper stage. 
20 IED management reviews and approves all procurement action. Any procured equipment is disposed in line with the 
section on “Administering Grant-Financed Technical Assistance Projects” in the Project Administration Instructions.  
21 Attachment 1 of the Staff Instruction on Business Processes for Knowledge and Support TA. 
22 Financial management, procurement capacity, risk assessment and management, and/or integrity due diligence.

8  Appendix 1

10  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestones 
 
Corporate and Thematic Evaluations (minimum of three each year by 2024) 
 
Corporate and thematic evaluations will follow standard IED protocols and processes, including the following 
indicative milestones, over a planned time range of up to 6 calendar quarters (18 months): 
1.1 Prepare concept paper and scoping mission (Q1) 
1.2 Prepare and approve evaluation approach paper (Q1) 
1.3 Interviews and consultations with relevant ADB management and staff (Q1–Q2) 
1.4 Field evaluation missions (Q2) 
1.5 Prepare and finalize story line (Q3) 
1.6 Prepare draft evaluation study report (Q3) 
1.7 Finalize evaluation study report; approval by director general, IED; and print and circulate (Q4–Q5)  
1.8 Pre-DEC discussions and DEC meeting (Q4–Q5) 
1.9 Post-completion dissemination, knowledge sharing, and outreach (Q6+) 
 
Country and Subregional Evaluations and Validations (minimum of four each year by 2024) 
 
Country evaluations and validations will follow standard IED protocols and processes, including the following 
indicative milestones, over a planned time range of 4 calendar quarters (12 months), with validations 
requiring half this time (usually 5 calendar months): 
2.1 Prepare concept paper and scoping mission (Q1) 
2.2 Prepare and approve evaluation approach paper (Q1) 
2.3 Interviews and consultations with relevant ADB management and staff (Q1–Q2) 
2.4 Field evaluation missions (Q2) 
2.5 Prepare and finalize story line (Q2) 
2.6 Prepare draft evaluation study report (Q3–Q4) 
2.7 Finalize evaluation study report; approval by director general, IED; and print and circulate (Q4) 
2.8 Pre-DEC discussions and DEC meeting (Q4) 
2.9 Post-completion dissemination, knowledge sharing, and outreach (Q4+) 
 
Sector Evaluations (minimum of three each year by 2024) 
 
Sector evaluations will follow standard IED protocols and processes, including the following indicative 
milestones, over a planned time range of 4 calendar quarters (12 months): 
3.1 Prepare concept paper and scoping mission (Q1) 
3.2 Prepare and approve evaluation approach paper (Q1) 
3.3 Interviews and consultations with relevant ADB Management and staff (Q1–Q2) 
3.4 Field evaluation missions (Q2) 
3.5 Prepare and finalize story line (Q2) 
3.6 Prepare draft evaluation study report (Q3–Q4)  
3.7 Finalize evaluation study report; approval by director general, IED; and print and circulate (Q4) 
3.8 Pre-DEC discussions and DEC meeting (Q4) 
3.9 Post-completion dissemination, knowledge sharing, and outreach (Q4+) 
 
Complementary and Quick Turn-around Evaluation Work (minimum of one each year by 2024) 
 
This work will follow standard IED protocols and processes, including the following indicative activities, 
applicable on a case-by-case basis (no strict timelines set for this type of work): 
4.1 Prepare concept or approach paper 
4.2 Interviews and consultations with relevant ADB management and staff 
4.3 Field evaluation missions 
4.4 Prepare and finalize story line 
4.5 Prepare draft report 
4.6 Finalize report; approval by director general, IED; and print and circulate 
4.7 Post-completion dissemination, knowledge sharing, and outreach

Appendix 1  11 
 
Evaluation Knowledge Management (EKM) Activities to Support Evaluations 
IED will continue its active engagement with key stakeholders in sharing knowledge, building capacity, 
conducting outreach and communication to raise the use and learning from evaluations. 
 
Continual Improvement of IED Information Systems 
To support its core evaluation and knowledge work IED will continually improve and modernize its 
information systems, including:  IED subsite (www.adb.org/evaluation), Management Action Record System 
(MARS), Evaluation Information System (EVIS), IED evaluation dashboard, and the cognitive search 
function. 
 
TA Management Activities 
 
Recruitment of consultants (Continuing; Q3 2020−Q4 2024) 
 
Preparing Independent Evaluations and Validations (Q1 2021−Q4 2024) 
  Inception 
  Field work 
  Report preparation 
  Report completion 
  Disclosure and dissemination  
 
Initiating and managing information services, partnerships and networking, knowledge sharing and 
learning (Q1 2021−Q4 2024) 
 
TA Administration and Completion (Q3 2020−Q4 2024) 
 
Inputs 
ADB: $6,500,000. Subproject 1 for $2.25 million will be financed by the Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF−6) and TASF−other sources, as follows: TASF-6 $1.75 million, and TASF-other $ 0.50 million. 
Subproject 2 will be for $2.15 million and Subproject 3 for $2.10 million, both to be financed by the TASF’s 
annual resource allocation to IED in the subsequent years. See Appendix 2 for further details on cost 
breakdowns. 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not Applicable 
a Strategy 2030 articulates the strategic, operational, and organizational priorities that ADB will pursue to raise its 
development effectiveness in supporting a more prosperous, inclusive, resilient, and sustainable Asia and Pacific by 
2030. IED’s Work Program and the evaluations supported by this cluster-KSTA will align to Strategy 2030. 
b ADB. 2008. Policy Paper: Review of the Independence and Effectiveness of the Operations Evaluation Department. 
Manila. ADB’s Evaluation Policy sets the mandate and key activities for IED: to undertake evaluation activities to help 
the Board of Directors, ADB Management, and decision makers in ADB developing member countries (DMCs) who are 
responsible for planning, designing, and implementing projects and programs to understand whether resources have 
been well spent, and whether the planned outcomes have been achieved. Evaluation covers all aspects of ADB 
operations  and  emphasizes effective  feedback  on  performance  and use  of lessons identified  to  improve the 
development effectiveness of ongoing ADB operations and to enhance their contribution to the development of ADB 
DMCs. 
c The 2020–2022 work program of IED, as approved by the Board of Directors, aligns with Strategy 2030 and was 
developed in close consultation with the Development Effectiveness Committee, ADB Management, and concerned 
departments. Evaluations over the 2020–2022 period will cut across all seven operational priorities and other major 
objectives of Strategy 2030.  
d Page view and download levels have historically been volatile. For example, total downloads in the preceding 3 years 
(2017 to 2019) ranged from 24,026 to 30,747. IED therefore tracks these indicators using 3-year averages.   
Source: Asian Development Bank (Independent Evaluation Department).

12  Appendix 2 
SUBPROJECT DESCRIPTIONS 
1.  The proposed knowledge and support technical assistance cluster (C-KSTA) is 
divided into three subprojects. Subproject 1 will support the delivery of evaluations to be 
mobilized in 2020 and completed through 2022, as set out in the IED work program, 2021–2022.1 
Subproject 2 is structured along the same lines and will support the delivery of evaluations in 
2022−2023, based on the next 3-year work program.2 Subproject 3 will support the delivery of 
evaluations in 2023−2024, based on the work program cycle for that period.3 
 
2.  Evaluations will be guided by established guidelines and protocols. An evaluation 
approach paper (EAP) will be prepared before starting an evaluation, providing its rationale, 
objective  and  scope,  methods  to  be  used,  resource  requirements,  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants, and dissemination plan—all in compliance with established ADB and IED guidelines 
and protocols. The EAP will be prepared for all evaluations except for validations of country 
partnership strategy final reviews and project completion reports. A concept note will be prepared 
for the annual evaluation review and major learning events. A consultant recruitment note will be 
prepared when diagnostic work is needed prior to finalizing an EAP.  
 
Table A2.1. Subprojects Profiles of Proposed C-KSTA 
Subproject 1  Supporting Evaluations for Development Effectiveness in Asia and the Pacific, 2020-
2022  
Indicative outputs   At least six corporate, thematic, country, and sector evaluations. 
and activities   Validations of country program final reviews. 
 Other complementary and quick turn-around evaluation work, outreach, information 
systems and methodological tools, and partnerships.  
Indicative   The subproject will be designed to support the achievement of the cluster outputs as and 
implementation  when needed during the implementation period. 
arrangements   Teams from IED’s Sector and Project, and Thematic and Country divisions, and two 
knowledge management units will be responsible for the administration and supervision of 
inputs and delivery of expected outputs from their assigned evaluation-related activities. 
 Implementation arrangements for ADB procurement will be finalized prior to approval of 
the evaluation approach paper (EAP). 
 The subproject will be designed to support the achievement of the cluster outputs as and 
when needed during the implementation period.  
 Areas for due diligence will be identified at the inception stage of an evaluation and 
activity. 
 Progress on key evaluation milestones will be tracked through mission back-to-office 
reports and ad hoc presentations or consultations on evaluation findings. 
 Engagement of consultants (individual and firm) and procurement of goods and services  
will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the 
associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions Disbursements will 
follow ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time 
to time). 
Implementation  November 2020 to December 2022 
schedule 
Subproject 2  Supporting Evaluations for Development Effectiveness in Asia and the Pacific, 2021-
2023 
Indicative outputs  Same as subproject 1 
and activities 
Indicative  Same as subproject 1 
implementation 
arrangements 
 
1 Where needed, subprojects 1–3 can support preparatory and/or advance work on evaluations during 2023−2024. 
2 Scope changes in the subproject memo can be made depending on the work program for 2022–2024. 
3 Scope changes in the subproject memo can be made depending on the work program for 2023–2025.

Appendix 2  13 
Implementation  January 2022 to December 2023 
schedule 
Subproject 3  Supporting Evaluations for Development Effectiveness in Asia and the Pacific, 2022-
2024 
Indicative outputs  Same as subprojects 1 and 2 
and activities 
Indicative  Same as subprojects 1 and 2 
implementation 
arrangements 
Implementation  January 2023 to December 2024 
schedule 
Source: Asian Development Bank (Independent Evaluation Department). 
 
3.  A team of staff and consultants will carry out each evaluation activity. IED will 
mobilize evaluation teams consisting of staff and, where needed, international and national 
consultants.4 The mix of staff and consultants will be driven by product type, subject matter, skills 
availability in-house, and staff workload. Staff deployment may cut across evaluation divisions 
and/or units, depending on the expertise required. Each study or activity concerned will be led by 
a member of staff acting as task manager. Each team will be responsible for formulating the study 
or  activity.  Implementation  oversight  (e.g.,  adequacy  of  staff,  consultant  processing,  and 
management), accountability for outputs, and communication with stakeholders will be delegated 
to the evaluation team leader. The size of each team will take account of a variety of factors 
including complexity and depth of analysis.  
 
4.  Consultant recruitment will follow standard procedures. Consultant recruitment (firm 
or individual) will begin when either a draft evaluation approach paper (EAP), concept paper, or 
consultant recruitment note is approved by director general, IED for interdepartmental review. 
Each evaluation will use internal commenters and external peer reviewers. Where appropriate, 
draft reports will be sent to the government and other stakeholders for feedback. All major 
evaluations will be circulated to the Board and Management and normally discussed by the DEC.  
 
5.  The TA will fund consulting requirements initially estimated at 181 consultants (for 
583 person-months) from 2020 to 2024.5 This consists of 75 international consultants (for 189 
person-months), 106 national consultants (for 394 person-months), and 28 international resource 
persons, from 2020 to 2024. 
 
6.  IED’s knowledge program will generally involve mixed methods and be informed by 
documentation  analysis,  key  informant  interviews,  economic  analysis,  and  site 
inspections.6  Each evaluation team will be supported by a mix of international and national 
consultants. Tentatively, a total of 42 international consultants (for 123 person-months) and 55 
national consultants (for 220 person-months) will be mobilized during 2020–2024. These are 
estimates for subprojects 1–3 of the C-KSTA. The number, type, expertise, and duration of 
assignment will vary depending on the sector or theme topic and the complexity of the evaluation. 
 
4 The indicative cost (individual consultants or consulting firm) and requisite fields of expertise will be finalized at the 
concept paper or evaluation approach paper stage. 
5 About 181 consultants (583 person-months) from 2020–2024 comprising 75 international consultants (189 person-
months), 106 national consultants (394 person-months) and 28 international resource persons (12 person-months), 
in 2020–2024. Annual consultant requirements for IED’s core evaluation work are 75 international consultants (63 
person-months); 35 national consultants (131 person-months) and 18 resource persons (4 person-months). At least 
6 international consultants (2 person-months) and 15 national consultants (30 person-months) are allocated for 
complementary evaluation work, knowledge sharing, information systems and networking. 
6 Corporate, thematic, country, or sector-wide evaluations; Systematic review; Topical papers. Other evaluative 
research and outreach materials.

14  Appendix 2 
The need for consultant services will be firmed up only at the inception stage of an evaluation 
(i.e., the consultant recruitment note, validation plan, evaluation approach paper).  
 
7.  International, in-country, and national consultants will be engaged as and when 
needed. Sector and theme specialists with relevant academic, professional and work experience, 
and evaluation expertise will be mainly engaged on individual assignments. Taking account of the 
scope  of  work  (e.g.,  a  stakeholder  survey,  focus  group  discussions,  and/or  key  informant 
interviews) and inputs involved, use of a consulting firm may be considered during preparation of 
the approach paper.  
 
8.  For the evaluation of nonsovereign operations, private sector consultants will (i) review 
ADB’s  private  sector  operations  strategies,  instruments,  portfolio  trends,  organization,  and 
processes;  (ii)  assess  individual  private  sector  operations  transactions  through  document 
reviews, field visits, and interviews with project sponsors, financiers, and relevant ADB staff;  
(iii) compare ADB’s operations with those of comparable multilateral financial institutions; and (iv) 
based on findings (i)–(iii), advise what changes are necessary to enhance ADB’s value addition.  
 
9.  For  topical  working  papers,  consultants  with  a  high  level  of  expertise  and  strong 
multilateral experience will help prepare short papers with a strong evaluative angle, connecting 
past lessons to current and prospective situations. They will draw lessons from evaluations (from 
ADB and other development partners) on topics of high operational relevance.  
 
10.  Resource persons and reviewers will be required to (i) comment on the draft report, 
focusing on areas that need strengthening; and (ii) give guidance on articulating key findings, 
lessons, and recommendations.7 Each evaluation will have about two peer reviewers for about 5 
working days per assignment. 
 
11.  The need for local consultants will be assessed at the EAP stage.8 Like international 
consultants, the number, mix, type, expertise, work experience, inputs and duration of assignment 
will vary depending on the topic and complexity of the study.  
 
12.  In-country consultants will (i) prepare country reports, initially focusing on relevant ADB 
implementation  experience,  and  current  practice  in  the  country  and  of  other  development 
partners; (ii) support evaluation mission field work, in particular facilitating logistics; (iii) arrange 
and conduct structured interviews with key informants; and (iv) support survey or questionnaire 
and data analysis. They are expected to have a sound understanding of development issues at 
the country level, ADB policies and operations, and development partners. 
 
13.  Headquarters-based consultants will include Philippine national consultants (research 
analysts, statisticians, and/or econometricians) who will support data collection and analytical 
work. These range from (i) literature reviews, policy and program analysis, (ii) review of project 
and other documents; (iii) portfolio analyses, benchmarking analyses, and preparation of country 
case studies; (iv) secondary data collection; (v) managing survey, questionnaire, and related data 
analyses; and (vi) other statistical support and/or econometric analyses. 
 
 
7  For resource persons, passports will be used to verify an expert’s nationality or member country eligibility. United 
Nations documents such as laissez-passers are not acceptable. 
8 National consultants may take a regional task to assist international experts if the task does not account for a 
substantial part of their terms of reference. If the TA envisages international travel by a national expert, these 
requirements must be added to their terms of reference.

Appendix 2  15 
14.  For nonsovereign operations, private sector experts will be engaged to (i) provide advice 
on  the  national  environment,  and  national  project  finance  and  financial  market  conditions; 
(ii) arrange and conduct structured interviews with key informants; and (iii) facilitate logistical 
arrangements. 
 
15.  IED will independently evaluate or validate ADB’s country program operations. 
Depending on country requirements, sector and/or thematic assessments are undertaken to 
provide inputs to the main country assistance program evaluation (CAPE). It also validates the 
findings and assess the quality of country partnership strategy final reviews. 9  The nature or scope 
of work of each product is described below.  
 
16.  The preparation of CAPEs and validations of CPS final reviews will require at least 27 
consultant evaluators (2.5 person-months each based on complexity). Specific tasks will include, 
among others, (i) review ADB assistance programs and assess their relevance, effectiveness, 
efficiency, sustainability, and impacts on strategic sector objectives; (ii) carry out key informant 
interviews, conduct surveys on the outcome and impact of ADB assistance, and discuss sector 
development issues and concerns with executing agencies and other stakeholders; and (iii) help 
assess the validity of ADB’s sector development strategies in the country. In addition, at least 12 
resource persons (3 person-months) or an advisor and/or external reviewer will (i) comment on 
the draft report, focusing on areas that need strengthening; and (ii) give guidance on articulating 
key findings, lessons, and recommendations.10 
 
17.  In-country evaluation consultants with previous exposure to development issues (sector 
and thematic) in the country will be recruited to (i) present an overview of the relevance and 
implementation of ADB sector strategies; (ii) assess and rate the achievement of project and 
program objectives, and the delivery of core sector, cross-cutting, and thematic programs; (iii) 
comment on ADB’s institutional positioning and performance in a sector; (iv) organize and 
facilitate  focus  group  discussions,  workshops,  and  meetings;  and  
(v) define important issues and lessons in a sector’s operations. 
 
18.  Headquarters-based  national  consultants  will  consist  of  evaluation  researchers  and 
coordinators. They will provide analytical support during data collection and analyses. These will 
include (i) desk reviews of project and other relevant documents, internet searches and other 
literature reviews; (ii) statistical and other technical support such as portfolio reviews, policy and 
program  analyses,  benchmarking,  and  statistical  and/or  econometric  analyses;  and  (iii) 
preparation of country case studies. The evaluation researchers and coordinators will (i) carry out 
quality assurance reviews on validated project and/or program completion reports and extended 
annual review reports, and/or (ii) help the project or program review report focal or group leader 
supervise and administer the validation process. 
 
19.  To complement IED’s core evaluation work, the TA will also fund quick turn-around 
evaluation work, management of information systems, and networking. Specific consultant 
services  for  quick  turnaround  thematic  and  sector  assessments  will  relate  to  knowledge 
dissemination  of  completed  evaluations  (i.e.,  advisory  and  expert  services  for  evaluative 
research) and management of information systems and technology. 
 
 
9 If IED’s work program does not include a CAPE for a country that is due for a new CPS, IED will validate a CPS final 
review (CPSFRV). The CPSFRV report then serves as the CAPE equivalent for the purpose of CPS preparation. 
10 For resource persons, passports will be used to verify an expert’s nationality or member country eligibility. United 
Nations documents such as laissez-passers are not acceptable.

16  Appendix 2 
20.  The C-KSTA may also support knowledge sharing and outreach events of selected 
evaluations. Consultants may be resource persons, panelists, or event coordinators. The nature 
and amount of consultant services will be determined during preparation of the approach paper 
of an evaluation or the concept paper of the outreach activity. 
 
21.  On a case-by-case basis, the C-KSTA will also support networking activities. For example, 
it may support IED cooperation with a range of development partners (with operations in Asia and 
the Pacific) including bilateral, multilateral, and regional organizations and institutions. At the 
country level, it will support collaboration with universities, civil society, evaluation associations, 
and government. 
 
22.  Subproject 1 for $2.25 million will be financed by the Technical Assistance Special 
Fund (TASF−6) and TASF−other sources. The breakdown for subproject 1 is: TASF-6 $1.75 
million, and TASF-other $ 0.50 million. Subproject 2 will be for $2.15 million and Subproject 3 for 
$2.10 million. Both will be financed by the TASF’s annual resource allocation to IED in the 
subsequent years.  
 
Table A2.2. COST ESTIMATES AND FINANCING PLAN 
  ($'000)   
  Subproject 1  Subproject 2  Subproject 3  Total 
(2020–2022)  (2022–2023)  (2023–2024)  (2020–2024)

a  Financed by the Asian Development Bank’s Technical Assistance Special Fund. Subproject 1 for $2.25 million will be 
sourced from the Technical Assistance Fund (TASF-6)  and TASF−other sources while subsequent projects will be

b  Includes the cost of external reviewers of evaluation reports and resource persons, advisors, and coordinators for 
evaluation outreach and knowledge-sharing activities.  
c  “Reports and communications” are budgeted under consultants, if subcontracted, or separately if procured by ADB 
directly. “Translation services” are considered non-consulting service provider contracts, with the related budget moved 
outside the consultants’ budget and treated separately. (Staff instruction on Procurement, January 2020) 
d “Seminars, workshops, and conferences” are held to acquire inputs for draft reports or support outreach to disseminate 
results. Costs include representation expenses in accordance with the memorandum issued by ADB’s Budget, People 
and Management Systems, and Strategy, Policy and Partnerships departments. (Use of Bank Resources: Regional 
Technical Assistance and Technical Assistance vs. Internal Administrative Expenses Budget, 26 June 2013). 
e Coordinators for outreach and knowledge-sharing activities may be provided by the consulting firms engaged or procured 
by ADB, which may now be non-consulting service provider contracts; if the latter, associated expenses are classified 
under the “Workshops, seminars and conferences” or “Miscellaneous administration and support cost” budgets. (Staff 
instruction on Procurement, January 2020) 
Source: Asian Development Bank (Independent Evaluation Department).

author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADF  –  Asian Development Fund 
  CAPE  –  country assistance program evaluation 
  CE  –  corporate evaluation 
  C-KSTA  –  knowledge and support technical assistance cluster 
  COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 
  CPS  –  country partnership strategy 
  DEC  –  Development Effectiveness Committee 
  EAP  –  evaluation approach paper 
  IED  −  Independent Evaluation Department 
  MARS  −  Management Action Record System 
  NSO  −  nonsovereign operations 
  PCR  −  project or program completion report 
  PPER  –  project or program performance evaluation report 
  PPP  –  public–private partnerships 
  SAPE  −  sector assistance program evaluation 
  SDG  −  Sustainable Development Goal 
SE  –  sector-wide evaluation 
  SPS  –  safeguard policy statement 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TCR  −  Technical assistance completion report 
  TASF  −  Technical Assistance Special Fund 
TE  –  thematic evaluation 
  TOR  –  terms of reference 
  XARR  –  extended annual review report 
 
 
 
NOTE{S} 
 
In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
   
Director General  Marvin Taylor-Dormond, Independent Evaluation Department (IED) 
Deputy Director General  Veronique N. Salze-Lozac'h, IED 
   
Team leader  Benjamin Graham, Principal Evaluation Specialist, IED  
Team members  Renato Lumain, Senior Evaluation Officer, IED 
  Karina Paula Marquez, Evaluation Assistant, IED 
   
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.
